Oh my God, I just got this email with—hold on, let me open this photo again. [gasp softly] This is Sarah's storefront. Sarah from... gosh, what was it, 2019? When she was literally three days from closing everything down. [very quietly] Look at this place now. There's a line of customers out the door, she's got, err... must be six employees in the photo? Maybe seven? [warm] And that sign—"Celebrating 5 Years of Growth"—she actually put that up. 

I remember sitting with her in that cramped back office, papers everywhere, her just... [sad] she was crying, you know? Saying she'd failed her kids. And I kept telling her, "Sarah, we can turn this around, we just need to—" well, honestly, I wasn't even sure myself at first. [pause] But we did that whole inventory restructure thing, changed her supplier contracts... [chuckle] God, she fought me on dropping that product line. 

[very sincerely] You don't get many of these moments. Where someone circles back years later to basically say "you saved my business." I mean, she did the work, obviously. All those late nights implementing everything. But seeing this now, knowing I was part of—hmm, I don't know, part of something that actually mattered? [emotional] That's... yeah. That's everything.
